0.author: JVLawnDarts
0.body: There are ways to get past this, apps don’t get deleted when clearing memory. You can download a shell that’ll store programs in deep storage that won’t show up in pgrm tab and rather in an application. I even made a little side hustle in highschool selling programs. Have fun with comp sci man it truly is a fun yet challenging thing to pursue.

2.author: xanderman524
2.body:
Fine. Ill concede a second time and allow you to break your no nazis rule and adress the argument on Filoni vs Favreau.

2.author: Few-Load9699
2.body:
I mean besides the “making of” specials and interviews where Filoni and Favreau both say it?

“I’ll concede the point where you addressed a fallacy I argued then tried to make it as if you argued started with a bad point” ftfy.

2.author: xanderman524
2.body: Ok. You mind walking me through how wanting to be part of a show makes you somehow worse than someone else by default, even though Favreau (1) is credited with directing fewer episodes than Filoni (3) and the two of them are listed simultaneously in the credits?

2.author: Few-Load9699
2.body: Those are just symptoms of the fact his best work was bastardized stories from other Star Wars media. He just renamed characters and removed the complexity.

2.author: xanderman524
2.body: And where is your source on that? Or perhaps could this be more personal bias interpreting things in a way to support said bias?

2.author: Few-Load9699
2.body:
Lol, bad batch for example. “Modified clones to make them better” you mean the Null arc troopers? “With specific roles” you mean like the Republic Commandos? Filoni just combined the two concepts together and then wrote a piss poor story for them.

The Mandalorian Arc in TCW “they nuked their planet to the point of being inhabitable” you mean the Krogans from Mass Effect? Then making the greatest non force using culture an aristocracy that’s pacifist? Boring and tropey writing. Especially when that could’ve been a great Alderaan story line and kept Mandos cool.

It’s not opinion. It’s observable. And those are just the fastest ones I thought of.

8.body:
He was told to drop it multiple times, but did he? No.
Hindsight is 20/20, wrong call in hindsight but in the moment there was no way to know if purple suit guy was the dead man's brother or not. It's definitely an unfortunate event. It's awful but lawful.

8.author: Kear_Bear_3747
8.body:
No he wasn’t, did you not watch the actual video? The time between when the cop says drop it to when opens fire is like a second and a half tops.

Also if you look carefully you can see how DOES drop it, and then still gets shot.

You just read the article without actually watching the footage which is what you were clamouring for, how hypocritical.

8.author: killin_commies
8.body:
I watched the video and purple shirt guy didn't drop it, even though his was told 3 times. the other officer grabs it but he still holds on, the purple shirt guy runs right after a shot is fired, that's when he drops it, yes the officer kept firing, adrenaline gives you tunnel vision, in a sense the officer was hyperfocused on the purple shirt guy.

Not to mention the guy in the background pointing out that purple shirt guy was POINTING the gun AT PEOPLE, Which obviously is a no-no.

8.author: Kear_Bear_3747
8.body:
He did drop it, if you watch the video closely you can see he drops it right before he was shot.

He was also given no time to drop it, the human brain cannot hear a command yelled at them and then comply within less than a couple seconds, the cop was clearly trained to just yell “drop it” over and over while he unloaded to cover his ass.

Think about the people who told the cop he had a gun; do you not think they regret opening their mouths because of the shite actions of that officer?

Also this was in Florida, isn’t that an open carry state? Did the police have legal authority to tell the guy to drop his firearm in the first place?

“A person may open carry for purposes of lawful self defence.”

11.author: Iamnothuman77
11.body:
what could you do in that situation tho? three cops will fuck you up with ease if needed, and they’re all armed. i understand the point you’re trying to make but what can you really do to “treat the situation as such” that wouldn’t make it worse for yourself.

if you’re not compliant with a good cop the situation escalates and there becomes issues when they’re not needed. and if it’s a bad cop you’re just poking the bear that’s probably causing problems already. 

i’m not entirely disagreeing with you’re point but there’s nothing you can do to make your scenario better in either case except cooperate.

11.author: Kear_Bear_3747
11.body: The police hold a position of public trust, that’s why it’s all or nothing. Ethnicity does not work the same way.

11.author: Kear_Bear_3747
11.body:
Okay let’s tweak the thought experiment: you KNOW all three cops are bad.

When they approach you would reasonably be defensive, say little, and try and remain within the public eye, yes?

The same should logically apply to an interaction where you don’t know if the cops are good or bad, because that’s the likeliest means of getting out of the situation safely. So because you don’t know which cops are the bad ones you treat them all as if they’re bad in order to protect yourself, and so a few bad apples have spoiled the bunch because you can’t trust that none of them are bad. 

That is a clear betrayal of public trust, and it’s well known cops cover for each other, and courts hesitate to prosecute them. Systemically it is a personal safety issue to assume any cops are good cops. They betray the public trust and border on being terrorists in some places.

11.author: Iamnothuman77
11.body:
would you mind elaborating on “be defensive”?

saying little and staying in public eye is completely fine tho. in any police scenario you should only say what you’re required. like legal identification info, or if you’re carrying a weapon (required in some states). and if you’re being detained “staying in public eye” sometimes isn’t possible bc if you’re detained and told to stay somewhere leaving that spot could become resisting, but doing what you can to be visible is perfectly acceptable. i was assuming you were talking about being straight up problematic

11.author: Kear_Bear_3747
11.body:
You would go out of your way to not be problematic, regardless of the legality of your words or actions because the cops would abuse their power against you.

That’s how people treat basically all cops now, because no one knows which are the good ones and which are the bad ones, and this is how we protect ourselves from not knowing which is which, and so the “few bad apples” have “spoiled the bunch.”

No one LIKES interactions with police. There’s a sense of dread that comes with it. Think about it.

18.author: pwdpwdispassword
18.body:
> The average beef burger takes around 634 gallons of water per. 

can you cite that?

i just don't understand where all that water goes (or comes from)

18.author: Draco_malfoy479
18.body:
https://wwf.panda.org/discover/knowledge_hub/where_we_work/amazon/amazon_threats/unsustainable_cattle_ranching/

It's 80%, my bad the 90% was from 1970.

18.author: Draco_malfoy479
18.body:
How many would you like? 


https://www.watercalculator.org/footprint/what-is-the-water-footprint-of/


https://www.latimes.com/food/dailydish/la-dd-gallons-of-water-to-make-a-burger-20140124-story.html


https://www.city.ac.uk/news-and-events/news/2019/10/one-hamburger-takes-2400-litres-of-hidden-water-to-make#:~:text='Water%20has%20been%20fed%20into,of%20a%20lot%20of%20water.

The water used not only for the cows to drink but they also need water to grow the food the cows eat.

18.author: pwdpwdispassword
18.body: this seems to rely on the Nepstad paper which is a decade-and-a-half old.

18.author: pwdpwdispassword
18.body:
>How many would you like? 

just one that clearly explains each of the sources of water:rainwater that feeds grass in pastures, rainwater collected for the cows to drink directly, irrigated water used for cows to drink directly, irrigated AND rain water used to water **each type of crop fed to cattle**.

> but they also need water to grow the food the cows eat.

right. one of the fodder crops fed to cattle is cottonseed. cottonseed isn't a feed crop, though: it's a byproduct of the textile industry.  so are we counting your teeshirt's water use in the water used in my hamburger?  this is why i am dubious about all the claims made about dairy water use.

not to mention: we get some of that water back directly as milk, and most of that water goes right back into the water table as urine.

18.author: pwdpwdispassword
18.body: I can't think of any major economic or technological or agricultural or dietary changes in the last 15 years, either.
